DIV1.P: THE BARON Kinkvervankotsdorsprakingatchdern.
A NEW MUSICAL COMEDY.
As performed at the THEATRE-ROYAL IN THE HAY-MARKET.
By MILES PETER ANDREWS, ESQ.
LONDON: Printed for T. CADELL, in the Strand.
M. DCC. LXXXI.

DIV1.HEAD: TO GEORGE COLMAN, ESQ.
DIV1.P: I TAKE the Liberty to inscribe this Dra∣matic Production to yourself, in Hopes it may be thought a Proof of your Judgment as well as of your Friendship. If, however, on Perusal, it should unfortunately be rejected as an Evidence of the one, your Treatment of it will incontestibly re∣main a Record of the other, towards

CLOSER.SALUTE: Your obliged and faithful Friend and Servant,

DIV1.HEAD: PREFACE.
DIV1.P:
THE very extraordinary circumstances which attended the hearing, or rather the not hearing of this piece, with the subsequent contentions which it occasioned, would seem sufficiently to call for its publication: these circumstances, however, the Author would certainly have foregone, ra∣ther than appear to make appeals from the deter∣mination of the Public; but having been charged with bringing on a polite Theatre many low and gross indecencies, many vulgar and improper allusions, justice, and not vanity, obliges him in some measure to rescue himself from so ungen∣tleman-like a conduct. In doing this, however, the Author begs that it may now, as well as for∣merly, be perfectly understood, he could never
mean to dispute the judgment, or oppose the de∣cided opinion of the town;—all he ever wished or requested was, a fair and candid trial, that their opinion might be supported by dignity and justice.

Without entering into the reasons why a piece, which had drawn three of the most brilliant au∣diences in London, should be taken from the stage, the Author desires to say a few words in his own behalf:—The amusement of his leisure hours was the first cause of his dramatic endea∣vours; the indulgence of the public has alone encouraged their continuance, and has always been his best reward. The ridiculous insinua∣tion that pecuniary advantage was the sole ob∣ject of his literary pursuits, scarcely deserves the Author's serious reply; though had his situation in life made such an attention necessary, he sees no reason why it should be branded with re∣proach. Circumstanced as he is, he takes the liberty to contradict every assertion of the kind; nor does he think any impartial person will ima∣gine, he could for a moment wish to impose a Drama upon the town against their consent, for the trifling consideration of a night's emolu∣ment: on the contrary he saw, or thought he saw, a great majority for two evenings in his
favour, and that majority consisting of many of the first and most respectable names in this country.

Mr. Colman, to be sure, as a Gentleman and a man of letters, knowing the difficulties which every dramatic writer is subject to, and the ene∣mies he has to encounter, took a warm and zea∣lous part in his support, for which he shall al∣ways think himself under great obligations: at the same time he makes no doubt, but Mr. Col∣man imagined himself justified in his conduct from the apparent sentiments of the audience; for though he might have felt for the Author as a friend, he never could have forgot his own situation so far, as to presume to dictate to the public entertainment in opposition to the public voice.

Thus much in justification of the repeated en∣deavours to have the Comedy quietly repre∣sented. That it contains not those numerous indelicacies ascribed to it, the Author hopes the perusal of his play will sufficiently prove: in con∣tradiction even of such a design, he begs it may be remembered, that having frequently had the honour of bringing his labours before the pub∣lic,
which they have deigned not to disapprove, he has some reason to plead past conduct in his favour: but were he even weak and absurd enough to offend seriously in this particular, such indelicacies, he is warranted in saying, could ne∣ver have escaped the discerning and judicious eye of Mr. Colman.

In a word, the Author begs again to repeat, that he does not mean to murmur at the public decree; but having been charged with inten∣tions he is not conscious of, and having been unkindly denied a candid hearing, after he had carefully erased every passage he could conceive objectionable, he takes the opportunity, when tumult has subsided, and the voice of conten∣tion is heard no more, to leave it in the breast of every dispassionate reader to determine, whe∣ther dulness and indecency pervade his scenes throughout.

Having said thus much in apology for the present publication, it may probably be ex∣pected that the Author should enlarge a little upon the nature of the piece itself, and account for the novelty which may in some measure have contributed to hurry its fate.—Characters and
situations drawn from ordinary life, being in every one's view, accommodate themselves to every apprehension; but manners and customs of other times and countries are not to be go∣verned by the standard of modern and domestic observation: it is requisite to consider how far they accord with the accounts we have of them, before we determine on their merits, and to re∣collect that, like strangers at our table, though they may not immediately strike the fancy, yet if received with caution and politeness, we may relish their converse as they grow familiar, and they may in the end turn out pleasant compa∣nions of our lives.

On perusing the anecdote from which this play is taken, the Author imagined the story might succeed on the stage, by the addition of some fresh personages in the Drama, and on that account he introduced the family that are not found in the Novel. To contrast the poverty and pride of the German Baron, with the vul∣garity and wealth of a Dutch trader would, as it appeared to him, produce that light and shade so necessary for dramatic effect; to make the son of that Dutchman the lover and husband of Cecil was, he thought, the most forcible me∣thod
of exciting the Baron's contempt and in∣dignation. If it should be objected that the language of the Hollanders is not polite, he can only answer, that he should think it incompa∣tible with their situation; and had he given them ideas, and made them discourse like people of fashion, such a dialogue, so far from heightening the merit of the piece, would, in his opinion, totally have destroyed it. The whimsical words put into the mouths of the Dutchman and his wife, and used in some of their songs, are absolutely Dutch phrases and terminations anglicised; they are not introduced as specimens of elegant writing, but purposely to enforce the characters; and therefore ought not to be tried by the nice rules of refined cri∣ticism. The preservation of character is, in the Author's opinion, the first distinction of dramatic writing; if he is mistaken, he alone must suffer for his error: but however lightly it may rest upon gentlemens' minds to pass hasty judgments on the works of others, he hopes it will be considered how painful it is, to a person of any sensibility, to experience those marked and pub∣lic censures, which, distinct from the merits or demerits of the piece, the dramatic, more than any other writer, is often doomed to bear; to
have his character arraigned, his private life in∣vestigated, and every sentiment of his heart tra∣duced and vilified, when the only crime he has committed has been a laudable desire of honest fame, and an anxious wish to entertain the pub∣lic, though with abilities perhaps too confined to bring those wishes to perfection.

DIV1.HEAD: PROLOGUE,
Spken by Mr. PALMER, in the Character of a HERALD.

LG.L: BEFORE the Baron and his suite come forth,
Behold a Herald to proclaim his worth!
This scroll Holds forth the Pedigree., the regiffer of antient blood,
Denotes him noble, long before the flood;
The pride of wealth his mighty mind disdains,
He boasts the riches flowing from his veins;
'Tis from that bank his daughter's dow'r is paid:
What, will no fortune-hunter court the maid?
Shall beauty, penny-less, remain forlorn
In single sweets upon the virgin thorn,
Tho' ripe sixteen, from tyrant statutes free,
A bride, by act of Parliament, may be?
But ah! our Baron's daughter none may wed,
Who does not bring credentials from the dead.
Yet pride of blood is not to be confin'd,
It reigns a general passion of the mind;
Hence the broad hatchment on the walls we see,
Hence oft the Herald touches the bright fee,
T'emblaze the brimstone on the vis-a-vis.
If any any here should need a Herald's aid,
I've coats of arms for all ranks, ready made!
A bunch of grapes the toper deep shall bear,
And in the front a burning ruby wear.
To suit the long-rob'd lawyer I decree
A double hand, in each a double fee;
Within the field, a golden fleece, confin'd
Betwixt two brambles, leaves its wool behind.
The eternal motto is, Eternal Gain!
And the supporters, Folly and Chicane.
Should a physician's coat of arms come next on,
Let him bear sables, with a grave and sexton!
Phials and gallipots surround the shield,
A purse and patient couchant in the field.
Arms for the Prince of Quacks are thus exprest:
He bears a Death's Head, rampant, for his crest;
Under the rose, let Esculapius nod!
Whilst Mercury, the nimble-finger'd God,
By subtile flame the bullion ore melts down,
And half a guinea melts to half a crown:
Let two gilt porters, rang'd on either side,
Support the scutcheon with gigantic pride;
Long mottos, charg'd with genuine classic fre,
Bid with a shock—the vulgar crowd retire;
And thick-fallen stars the blazing scutcheon grace,
Worthy the Quack, and worthy of King's Place!
In various coats polygamy might shine,
And thus emblazon'd suit a deep Divine;
A crescent moon the upper point adorns,
In the wan splendor of increasing horns;
Cupid Briareus in the center strives,
With hundred hands to rule a hundred wives;
Near him an Argus▪sits, his watchful guide,
To prove he wants a hundred eyes beside.
Last for our bard—what coat shall I provide?
Bards may want coats of arms, and other coats beside.
His title to a coat 'tis you must name,
His best supporters, if he merits fame!

DIV1.HEAD: EPILOGUE,
Spoken by Mrs. WILSON, in an old German Dress.

LG.L: NO wondering, good folks—I've done my best—
Bedizen'd a-la-German, like the rest!
Thanks to our Author and his Gothic play,
Fine havock has our wardrobe felt to-day;
Old modes new made, such flouncing and fresh facing,
Such trimming, cutting, butt'ning and tight lacing;
Great, squat, old German milleners in troops,
'Squires in trunk hose, and fat Dutch frows in hoops;
'Twere odd, indeed, if 'midst this general riot,
A female's curious temper could be quiet;
So, like our mother Eve, resolv'd to see
If some old fig-leaf garment suited me,
Up stairs I stole, without our prompter's call,
And here I am—Ruff—Fardingale and all!
Well, gentlemen, what think ye? do I strike ye?
Speak truth for once, and say you do not like me.
'Tis true no ton—no prince's stripe I boast—
Choice requisite to make a modern toast;
No Vestris blue, to tempt one spark to marriage,
No brimstone, I confess it, in my carriage;
But a plain, simple, strange, old-fashion'd creature,
Without e'en art enough to banish nature.
Yet still from this odd dress some uses flow,
Arm'd cap-a-peé one dares to meet a beau;
This frizzled ruff, methinks, looks like resistance,
And whalebone petticoats say—"keep your distance!"
"Psha! cries my Lord,—now pox—it is one's duty
"To lop off all incumbrances from beauty;
"Nature I love most liberally display'd,
"Charms without veil, and lawns without a shade;
"Give me the fair who laughs at ogling, sighing,
"Drills you recruits, hunts fox-hounds, and shoots flying,
"Tow'rs o'er her sex, a coachman in—a wig,
"And drives in hand—six ponies, and—a gig."
If this is ton—I easily foresee
The judgment that awaits my dress and me:
I own bad habits should be laid aside—
And this remov'd—your censures should subside.
One serious truth, and one is not too hard—
I bring, ye fair, commission'd from our bard:
He bids me say—that howsoe'er we boast
"To drive, hunt, shoot, talk loud, and be a toast;
"To win by gentler manners should be ours,
"To soothe the troubles of domestic hours;
"And say those manly ladies what they will,
"Our surest maxim is—be women still."

DIV1.HEAD: DRAMATIS PERSONAE.
DIV1.P: SCENE, The Baron's Castle.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT I.
DIV2.STAGE: The SCENE represents a great Square in Gottingen, on one Side a Mountebank's Stage with a Mob standing round it; on the other, People with Stalls, Barrows, &c.; a Recruiting Party is heard advancing, who after a Symphony come on, singing and marching to quick Time.

LG.L: LET's be jolly,
'Tis a folly
Ever to be melancholy:
Hither, my heroes, come, come, come,
Move to the sound of the drum, drum, drum.

DIV3.HEAD: SOLO,

LG.L: If by niggard fortune bounded,
If by scclding wives confounded,
Or by squalling brats surrounded,
To the drum, to the drum
Quickly come, quickly come.

LG.HEAD: II.
LG.L: If that one love can't content ye,
And you wish for wives in plenty,
Follow me, I'll find you twenty:
To the drum, to the drum
Quickly come, quickly come.

DIV3.STAGE: (Retires among the crowd.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor.
SP.P: (from the Stage) Here, mine dere boys, and my merry meysies, listen to me; here is de small pill to cure de great ill—he! he! he!—bon!—look at dis little sweet box of salve; ver good to put out de film in de eye, and de chalkstone in de toe. Here is de cataplasm for de head∣ach, and de sprain'd ancle; dis is de pill for de lady who make de slip to take away de tumor, and de swell—but here is de famous electaire, which I always give to mine fair countrywoman for nothing at all, except pay for de box. De groote specific for de younk lady in lof who has lost her heart, so dat it shall appear de same as be∣fore, and fit for de closest inspection.

SP.SPEAKER: Serjeant
SP.P:
(advancing). Now, my bloods of steel, now is the time to serve the Emperor, and fight like fury! All Europe is flying to arms, the Dutch and all; so you are sure of plunder wherever you go. Why then
stay here, living among mechanics at home, when you may die like gentlemen in the field of honour?

SP.SPEAKER: Doct.
SP.P: Die! don't be afraid of dat, mine friends; you cannot die while I can cure: here is de restorative for de cannon-ball: dis give de new leg, and de new eye.

SP.SPEAKER: Serj.
SP.P: Well done, Doctor; give a new heart too to them that want it.

SP.SPEAKER: Doct.
SP.P: Fight away, mine boys! get wound, get sore, loose blood, loose head, no matter, I shall find you another. He! he! he!—bon!

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Franzel, in Regimentals.

SP.SPEAKER: Franz.
SP.P: How fare you, Serjeant? you seem in good spirits.

SP.SPEAKER: Serj.
SP.P: Yes, your honour, I am laughing at the Doctor; he does all he can to help the service—I sup∣pose he looks upon every raw recruit as a fresh patient; and I dare say, between us both we shall do the business of half Gottingen.

SP.SPEAKER: Franz.
SP.P: Well, Serjeant, they want you now at the Eagle, so I'll dismiss you for the present—(whispers him.)

SP.SPEAKER: Serj.
SP.P: Come along, my lads—Let's be jolly, &c.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Rubrick—advancing, sees Franzel.
DIV3.P: Do my eyes deceive me? What, my old friend and schoolfellow, Franzel Boterham!

SP.SPEAKER: Franz.
SP.P: The same, my dear Rubrick, and as much your's as ever.

SP.SPEAKER: Rub.
SP.P:
But who would have thought of seeing you
with a fife and recruiting serjeant at your heels, in this seat of learning, this repository of books, cobwebs and short cassocks, this scene of dulness, where we Germans acquire a double portion of stupidity?

SP.SPEAKER: Franz.
SP.P: Why it may appear odd—but my reasons, to reason logically, are twofold—the first, because my party are ordered into this part of the country; the next, because I expect my worthy father here every moment; and I, like a dutiful son and an obedient officer, am come hither to perform two obligations at once.

SP.SPEAKER: Rub.
SP.P: And, pray what can have induced your wor∣thy father, as you call him, to leave Holland and visit Gottingen? Formerly, I recollect he used to be a a little more attentive to the main chance.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: The very reason that brings him hither, for you must know, that said attention has made him at∣tach himself to a small territory in this neighbourhood; and he is coming to see that it is not run away from him.

SP.SPEAKER: Rub.
SP.P: Explain yourself.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: Why then in two words, my careful father has a mortgage upon a castle which belongs to Baron Kinkver—damn his long name! I can never pronounce it; but it contains about fifteen syllables, and he lives within a league of this place.

SP.SPEAKER: Rub.
SP.P: Yes, yes, I know him—tho' I believe you'll find his name and his pedigree longer than his rent-roll.

SP.SPEAKER: Franz.
SP.P: I suppose so, and the Family Tree the only one upon the estate. But, apropos, as I am going to be introduced, pray inform me what the houshold consists of.

SP.SPEAKER: Rub.
SP.P:
That is more than I am able to do; but there's
the Baron's physician, who seems to have finish'd his morning's practice, he will, I dare say, give you all the information you want.

DIV3.STAGE: (The Doctor having put up his Apparatus, leaves his Stage, and comes forward.)

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: (to the Doctor) Doctor, permit me to return you thanks for the assistance you gave my party just now.

SP.SPEAKER: Doct.
SP.P: Monsieur Officier—I was assist mine self, to encourage de wounds, is to have an opportunite to shew a mine skill in de cure of dem; he! he! he!—bon!

SP.SPEAKER: Rub.
SP.P: Very good, Doctor; your advertisements here leave us no room to doubt of your abilities.

SP.SPEAKER: Doct.
SP.P: I cure all de evils, except one—de want of money. He! he! he!—bon!

SP.SPEAKER: Franz.
SP.P: Aye, that's a case, I take it, which is not so easily remedied—but your great practice must exempt you from any such disorder.

SP.SPEAKER: Rub.
SP.P: Yes, the Doctor attends all the first families in the country, as soon as he has dispatched the poor people in town.

SP.SPEAKER: Doct.
SP.P: Ver true; but de groot families are sometimes trouble vid dat maladie—de weak purse. He! he! he!—bon!

SP.SPEAKER: Franz.
SP.P: He! he! he! I think that is not bon! But the great Baron who resides here hard by—

SP.SPEAKER: Doct.
SP.P: Oh dat be de infirmity dere too—but I have de great discretion: I make no discoverie! every body rely upon me.

SP.SPEAKER: Rub.
SP.P: I don't doubt it.

SP.SPEAKER: Doct.
SP.P: Mynheer de Baron, he say to me, Docteur, I trust you wid de secrets of my famillie, because I see you have de discretion: you know I have von handsome daughter—I want to keep dat conceal from all de world, but you have ver good understand, Mr. Doctor▪ and upon my vord de Baron be a ver discerning man.

SP.SPEAKER: Rub.
SP.P: The Baron does you no more than justice.

SP.SPEAKER: Doct.
SP.P: Den dere be Captain Hogrestan, groot friend of de Baron; he desire me to make his address to de younk lady▪ I promise him I would: so I say nothing; for I make no discoverie! but I believe she have no groot paffion for Monsieur Hogrestan. He! he! he!—bon!

SP.SPEAKER: Rub.
SP.P: Probably he may be too old for her.

SP.SPEAKER: Doct.
SP.P: Dat is no mine business; he be doubtless a good deal age, but I no mention it—I say to him, Cap∣tain Hogrestan, you was little old, and von little ugly; but vat den! you keep your own counsel, nobody know it. He! he! he!—bon!

SP.SPEAKER: Franz.
SP.P: Very good advice; I hope he profited by it.

SP.SPEAKER: Doct.
SP.P: No, he was fancy himself agreeable, he be ver antient famillie; de Baron love dat more dan any thing—but I make no discoverie!—I tell Monsieur Ho∣grestan it won't do—de younk frow has no virtu, she no like antiques.

SP.SPEAKER: Franz.
SP.P: And pray, Doctor, what says the Baron to this?

SP.SPEAKER: Doct.
SP.P:
Oh, I have de respect for de Baron, so I keep my own counsel—but he be der duivel attach to de hon∣neur of his famillie; he has all deir picture, which cover de whole chateau from top to bottom; 'tis all von grand portrait of his ancesteurs!—and den he is ver ob∣stinate; Monsieur le Baron he command every ting just
as he please! Dere is de Chaplain and minself never speak von word—dat is in his presence.

SP.SPEAKER: Franz.
SP.P: Then you are undoubtedly right to take that liberty behind his back.

SP.SPEAKER: Doct.
SP.P: Excusie, excusie—I am ver cautious in dat article, and lof discretion! But, gentlemen, I must wish you good morning; I am much presse' great many familles to visit! de grand seigneurs wid de little ill—but I make no discoverie! Gentlemen, your most obe∣dient! I am in great hurry! Gentlemen, I am your ver humble servant! Oh I am so press, I cure every ill but de weak purse! He! he! he!—bon! [Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Rub.
SP.P: (laughing) Ha! ha! ha! well done, Dr. Dis∣cretion! You see, my dear friend, he has given you much better information than I could do.

SP.SPEAKER: Franz.
SP.P: Yes, and I am happy to find the castle affords modern as well as antient family pictures to amuse one.

LG.L: Give me the melting eye that speaks
The softness of the heart,
The youthful glow, the blushing cheeks,
The bloom that baffles art.
The mind by time not render'd hard
Ere fashion's stains appear,
That with the smile of fond regard
Can blend the feeling tear.
Give me, &c.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE, An Antichamber.
DIV3.STAGE: The Baron's Castle discovered; servants entering with scrubbing-brushes, brooms, &c.

SP.SPEAKER: Groot.
SP.P: Lord, Dagran, how tired I am!

SP.SPEAKER: Dag.
SP.P: Why to be sure, Mrs. Grootrump, these cursed old apartmenes do take a consumed deal of clean∣ing.

SP.SPEAKER: Groot.
SP.P: Yes, and we are to do all the business by ourselves;—I am sure you and I work from morning till night, and from night till morning again; but 'tis all labour in vain, I see!

SP.SPEAKER: Dag.
SP.P: I am sorry for it! but these devilish long gal∣leries (with the wind coming in at one end, the rain at another, and the dust on all sides) would conquer the patience of Job.

SP.SPEAKER: Groot.
SP.P: Aye; and when I have done here, then am I forced to trundle down into the kitchen; serve up breakfast; cook the dinner; wash the dishes, and scrape enough out of them to make supper; besides dreffing our young lady in the morning; writing out the accounts at noon; and tucking up the old Baron at night! Oh! I can never hold it long! If it was not for the comfort you give me, I should be found some morning lifeless in my bed.

SP.SPEAKER: Dag.
SP.P: Come, come, Grootrump, am not I as hard ridden as you are?

SP.SPEAKER: Groot.
SP.P: No, no! not altogether.

SP.SPEAKER: Dag.
SP.P:
Don't I assist in cleaning the castle? Don't I sweep the stable, take care of the horses, feed the hogs, dig in the garden, and say amen to the curate;
besides waiting on my master Hogrestan, who's the very devil himself for tiring a person.

SP.SPEAKER: Groot.
SP.P: Aye! what with his long account of storms and breaches—

SP.SPEAKER: Dag.
SP.P: Aye, but we have met with some disasters, as I can safely say, who have gone through the same duty with him.—A great many rubs (rubbing with the brush) a great many rubs, that's certain! and then to get no higher than a Lieutenant at the age of fifty; sad pro∣motion!

SP.SPEAKER: Groot.
SP.P: Yes, but he hopes to get a better promo∣tion now; for he seems to have fixed an eye on our young lady, in an honourable way; and a shameful thing it is at his time of life, I can tell him.

SP.SPEAKER: Dag.
SP.P: Very true—and then so humble, and so dis∣tant, that he'll never come to the point.

SP.SPEAKER: Groot.
SP.P: Well, give me an active man for my mo∣ney, (pushing the chair forward.) None of your shrivell'd decay'd old gentlemen, that make love with∣out knowing how.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Hogrestan, with a Stick and long Pipe; takes two or three Strides about the Stage, without noticing them.

SP.SPEAKER: Dag.
SP.P: None of your tall, aukward, forlorn figures, that stride about a place like a ghost! that one scarce knows when they're present or not.—Always thinking of something else, poring and puffing.

SP.SPEAKER: Groot.
SP.P: (Leaning over the chair) No, nobody minds such fusty people—

SP.SPEAKER: Dag.
SP.P: (Over another chair opposite) No, no, no∣body cares for them, more than an old—

DIV3.STAGE: [Hogrestan comes betwixt 'em, and drops his Stick, as if absent, with great force, and they start.]

SP.SPEAKER: Hog.
SP.P: —Jack boot! they could not mean it!

SP.SPEAKER: Groot.
SP.P: (In a fright) Lord bless us! I hope he has not over-heard us!

SP.SPEAKER: Dag.
SP.P: O don't be alarmed, he thinks too much to hear any thing.

SP.SPEAKER: Groot.
SP.P: Then I'll take care not to give him another opportunity. [Exit running.

SP.SPEAKER: Hog.
SP.P: Why, Dagran, do'st thou recollect my old regimental boots, that hung across the Baron's great aunt, in the gallery? those that I wore at my first cam∣paign?

SP.SPEAKER: Dag.
SP.P: To be sure, your honour—I shall never for∣get them! They came up (if I recollect) to your Honour's hips, and as roomy as the boot of a stage coach.

SP.SPEAKER: Hog.
SP.P: Then thou rememberest when Count Grun∣derditch and Baron Filchenberg gave me a most mortal affront by putting a leg of mutton, and other provi∣sion, taken on our march, unperceiv'd by me, into the top of them, and when I paraded into the next quarters, they tumbled out, to the confusion of the whole corps.

SP.SPEAKER: Dag.
SP.P: And how I said upon the occasion, that such a gallant gentleman as Lieutenant Hogrestan—such a wonderful officer—

SP.SPEAKER: Hog.
SP.P: Yes, who had seen service—

SP.SPEAKER: Dag.
SP.P: Such a strict disciplinarian, says I—attach'd to flogging from his infancy—

SP.SPEAKER: Hog.
SP.P: Aye, from theory—

SP.SPEAKER: Dag.
SP.P: Yes, and from practice—knows all the per∣fections of a soldier; so upright, and so unforgiving! so clean and so poor; such a length of time in the service, and no promotion!

SP.SPEAKER: Hog.
SP.P: Very true, Dagran.

SP.SPEAKER: Dag.
SP.P: O, says I, it's a mortal shame! a leg of mutton in a soldier's boots! I am sick at the thought!

SP.SPEAKER: Hog.
SP.P: I am obliged to thee—thou hast long been a faithful servant to me, and interests thyself in all my distresses; so come hither! I have something to impart to thee of great consequence; see that the door is fas∣tened.

SP.SPEAKER: Dag.
SP.P: Ay, your honour, the door is fast enough—but here are such a damn'd number of chinks and cran∣nies in this old mansion, that there is no certainty of not being overheard at any time—it is a rare piece of antiquity—this castle, that's the truth on't.

SP.SPEAKER: Hog.
SP.P: What think'st thou then of my becoming master of it?

SP.SPEAKER: Dag.
SP.P: What, by storm, your honour? Yes, we could soon—

SP.SPEAKER: Hog.
SP.P: No!—

SP.SPEAKER: Dag.
SP.P: By sap—I remember—

SP.SPEAKER: Hog.
SP.P: No, good Dagran, I mean by marriage; thy poor head is always running upon fortifications, breast-works, horn-works, and—

SP.SPEAKER: Dag.
SP.P: Ay, your honour, it's all the same thing.

SP.SPEAKER: Hog.
SP.P: I hope not. Thy ignorance, good Dagran, saves thee from all intention of offence—however, I must inform thee, that there are great difficulties to struggle with.

SP.SPEAKER: Dag.
SP.P: So much the better for your honour's courage.

SP.SPEAKER: Hog.
SP.P: But then, Dagran, think how heavily it would sit upon a gentleman, whom fortune has long borne hard upon to be thus crossed in his affections at fifty years of age, in his first paffion, the very infancy of his love, the very dawn of his regard—

SP.SPEAKER: Dag.
SP.P: The second childhood, your honour would say.

SP.SPEAKER: Hog.
SP.P: I would not say any such thing! but consider how difficult it is to attack with vigour, and yet win with gentleness; to open one's trenches, and not dis∣cover one's weakness!

SP.SPEAKER: Dag.
SP.P: Lord, your honour, don't mind, you'll disco∣ver nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Hog.
SP.P: Honest Dagran, thy zeal overpowers thee! thou forgettest that ugly wound I received in my last campaign.

SP.SPEAKER: Dag.
SP.P: The enemy will think it an honourable mark.

SP.SPEAKER: Hog.
SP.P: Sure thou dost not remember that—

SP.SPEAKER: Dag.
SP.P: We must then give up the point.

SP.SPEAKER: Hog.
SP.P: (shaking the ashes from his pipe) I have nothing left to console me.

SP.SPEAKER: Dag.
SP.P: Your honour's pipe is out.

SP.SPEAKER: Hog.
SP.P: (looking at his pipe in a melancholy posture)—Not a spark remaining.

SP.SPEAKER: Dag.
SP.P: Then it had better be laid aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Hog.
SP.P: And yet to fly from one's standard—

SP.SPEAKER: Dag.
SP.P: What signifies, if we cannot support it?

SP.SPEAKER: Hog.
SP.P: An old soldier, and yield!

SP.SPEAKER: Dag.
SP.P: (taking fire) Zounds! your honour we'll not run!

SP.SPEAKER: Hog.
SP.P: It would be a shame to desert the field o ho∣nour.

SP.SPEAKER: Dag.
SP.P: We'll die in the bed of it, that we will.

SP.SPEAKER: Hog.
SP.P: Thou revivest me, good Dagran; we'll rally our forces; they shall yet see I can do something.

SP.SPEAKER: Dag.
SP.P: A great deal.

SP.SPEAKER: Hog.
SP.P: If we could but—

SP.SPEAKER: Dag.
SP.P: Once gain a little advantage, and we may do what we please.

SP.SPEAKER: Hog.
SP.P: I don't know that.

SP.SPEAKER: Dag.
SP.P: Lord, your honour, there's the enemy recon∣noitering us in yonder gallery; therefore, your honour▪ pluck up a good heart; the first stroke is half the battle.

SP.SPEAKER: Hog.
SP.P: Stand to your arms then.

SP.SPEAKER: Dag.
SP.P: Ready.

SP.SPEAKER: Hog.
SP.P: To the right about.

SP.SPEAKER: Dag.
SP.P: March!

SP.SPEAKER: Hog.
SP.P: (marching out) I'll attack with the van-guard.

SP.SPEAKER: Dag.
SP.P: And I'll assist your honour in the rear.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE, An old Library.
DIV3.STAGE: The Baron and Curate discovered at Cards.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: Let me see, Curate; ay, hearts must be trumps, I say.

SP.SPEAKER: Curate.
SP.P: Umph! I suppose I have not one; but it's all for the best.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: Have you the deuce? If not, I'm all fours.

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.P: I told you I had not one—I dare say you took care of that.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: To be sure, when Emperors condescend to play—

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.P: I know that well enough; but we have no∣thing to play for—so it's all for the best.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: Come, don't mutter! but deal; if you turn up Jack, you must deal again.

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.P: Ah, very well, I must submit—(deals)—Well, Baron, I have highest in every suit.

SP.SPEAKER: Baron.
SP.P: (rising) Hah! I won't play any more.

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.P: (rising and laughing) He! he! he!

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: What's that you are laughing at? have not I repeatedly commanded you never to laugh, except when I tell a story, or say one of my comical things?

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.P: He! he! he! I thought that was a comical thing. He! he! he!

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: Sometimes you are a good sensible fellow enough, and if you were a little more active about the house, and knew something of gardening, and breaking horses, and could kill a pig, you would make a good tolerable kind of chaplain.

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.P: Umph! I am sure I do as much as most chap∣lains; I neglect all the parish duties to perform your's.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: Come, don't look surly. Fetch me a chair. You seem out of humour—sing me a song.

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.P: A song! I'm quite out of voice.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: Sing!—Come, give me the old family canticle that my grandfather made when he presented his fpouse with a new pair of garters, with two bleeding hearts upon the top of them, and the edges stitch'd with silver: I think I see them before me! my great ancestor gal∣lantly putting them on t this instant!

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.P: Lord, Baron, it's so long a story, and so long ago, that I have almost forgot it.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: How!

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.P: But I'll give you a little of my own nonsense; he! he! I always think that best.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: Your own nonsense, puppy! tho' if it's your own, I make no doubt of its absurdity, and any thing will do to amuse one; but mind, none of your capering about, and making odd faces, but sing in a grave, gen∣tleman-like stile, as you ought to do.

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.P: Very well, I'll be as grave as I can.

LG.L: In days of yore, as I've been told,
With a humdrum woundy length of line-o,
There liv'd a Baron bluff and bold,
With a strum-strum very little coin-o;
Means, I grant ye,
Rather scanty,
But great store of line-o;
Strim-stram, pamma diddle, lara bona, ring tang, ring tang, very little coin-o.

LG.HEAD: II.
LG.L: A chaplain too he had, d' ye see
With a stomach always glad to dine-o,
And a merry wag, they say, was he,
With a likewise very little coin-o:
Always willing,
Fond of filling,
With good store of wine-o;
Strim-stram, pamma diddle, &c.

LG.HEAD: III.
LG.L: The Baron was great, and fond of state,
None could his equal be;
He led his folks about,
Both within and without,
And together they made up three.
The chaplain was ever most wonderful clever,
Many rare jokes he made,
He often wish'd to speak,
Tho' not suffer'd once a week,
So he sung what could not be said.

LG.HEAD: IV.
LG.L: The Baron, it seems, was sometimes pleas'd
With his pictures all so old and fine-o;
The chaplain, I hear, was sometimes teaz'd,
But never was allow'd to repine-o:
Constant duty,
Little booty,
Were his lot but mine-o!
Strim-stram, pamma diddle, lara bona, ring tung, ring tang, o! it is divine-o!

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: (interrupting) Hold, hold; what, will you never have done with your stupidity?

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.P: Why it runs so glib, I could go on for ever.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: Then I say, let me never hear it again—if you do! you understand me?

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.P: Upon my word, Baron, I can't say I do.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: Why you lump of obscurity! I hope you don't mean to infinuate that I am not as clear as the day?

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.P: Why, Baron, you grow worse—but it's all for the best.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: Don't answer me, I say! I tell you that you are an ungrateful fellow!▪ Don't I keep you like a gentleman out of charity? don't I behave to you like a friend? treat you with respect, and only desire you to do the little offices in the Castle?

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.P: Well, Baron, and don't I do them all?

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: Why, sirrah, don't I treat you in the gen∣tlest, and most polite manner? and don't I know that you were taken from a dunghill? and don't I know I am the first plant in the world? and don't I know that I never mention all this?

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.P: I see you never do.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: And how durst you say that—heh! what was it that you said?

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.P: Indeed, Baron, I have forgotten.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: There again! have not I told you a thousand times never to forget any thing?

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Grootrump with a Letter.

SP.SPEAKER: Groot.
SP.P: Lord! here's such a rumpus! and such a knocking at the gate, that one's obliged to go and see who it is!—Sir, there's a Dutchman, with a dozen pair of trowsers on, has brought this letter.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: Letter! let's look at it! I hope there's no postage! umph!—What's this?—(Reads)—

LETTER.P:
“At sight, please to receive this my first letter of ad∣vice—Mefrow and I, set out in the trekskuyt from Amsterdam last Saturday, both in good order and well conditioned, for your Castle, where we hope to
arrive on Wednesday;”—Why zounds that's to-day! “”Shall come by way of Gottingen, to dispose of a cargo of tobacco, and call for my son; shall be hap∣py to find you well, if 'tis only to receive the in∣terest due on the little mortgage I have of your's—so God send us to our desired port in safety.
LETTER.CLOSER: Exchange ⅝ Agio 2¾ Peter Jan Van Boterham."

DIV3.P: Here's a fellow with his Exchange, and his Agio! bringing all his family to my house, to demand money; little mortgage, does he call it? Why half my estate is his, and the whole may be shortly for what I know.—The venerable Castle, magnificent furniture, valuable pictures, statues! and all!—he once promised to assist me; but what are treaties to Dutch traders? however we'll make the best on't—Come, Grootrump, we are going to have company, and must keep up ap∣pearances, so stir your stumps.

SP.SPEAKER: Groot.
SP.P: Lord, Sir, there's no stirring any thing without money.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: Psha—see that we are well provided.

SP.SPEAKER: Groot.
SP.P: Yes, Sir, provided we pay for it; but the butcher says he'll trust our house no longer.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: What, does he say any thing against the credit of my family?

SP.SPEAKER: Groot.
SP.P: No, he says there has been too much credit in your family.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: A scoundrel! but I'll punish him—I'll pay him off, and discharge him.

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.P: No, no, you had better employ him again, and not pay him off at all—that's the best way, and the cheapest, Baron.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: Don't you pretend to give your advice. Go, Grootrump, make a small fire in the great gallery, and uncover the family pictures, particularly those by my father's side.

SP.SPEAKER: Grootrump.
SP.P: Yes, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: And order the stable-door to be lock'd, ad the key to be lost.

SP.SPEAKER: Groot.
SP.P: Yes, sir: lost or found, I'm sure it's not of much consequence, for every thing is gone to rack and manger.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: And do you, Curate, be a little more active, and step down into the yard, and kill a couple of geese; but take care to save the giblets, and all the odds and ends, because perhaps you may have a finger in the pye afterwards.

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.P: A finger in the pye afterwards! but I shall probably have a hand in it before; so it's all for the best. (Going.)

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: Do you hear? step into the wardrobe, and brush the rich fashionable waistcoat that my old uncle used to wear; but take care and don't hurt the em∣broidery.

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.P: Very well, I am sure I can't hurt the fashion.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: And then, do you hear, sir? put the family wig into pipes. [Exeunt.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE continues.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Cecil, with a Spanish Guitar in her Hand; Ho∣grestan following—Dagran after.

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: Lord, Signior Hogrestan, don't disturb y singing; I will finish my song, I am resolved.

SP.SPEAKER: Hog.
SP.P: Fairest creature, pursue your entertainment—far be it from the respectful Hogrestan, to give the smallest possible interruption to your wishes; but if the utmost deference, the most profound respect—the—

SP.SPEAKER: Dag.
SP.P: Sir, Sir!—that will never do—make a close attack.

SP.SPEAKER: Hog.
SP.P: I am going—I say young lady, if the most distant—

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: (archly) Well, well, keep your distance—I don't want you to say any thing, listen to my shep∣herdess.

LG.L: And do you think he tells me true,
And are you sure 'tis so?
For if that's all he means to do,
Why don't he let me go?
But there's no saying what it is,
There's no one can guess;
Why that which causes most our bliss,
Is what we least confess.

SP.SPEAKER: Hog.
SP.P: I could hear you for ever! that enchanting voice—

SP.SPEAKER: Dag.
SP.P: Yes, Sir, but let her hear a little more of your's.

SP.SPEAKER: Hog.
SP.P: I will, I will—don't be too warm!

SP.SPEAKER: Dag.
SP.P: Don't you be too cold, your Honour.

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: Do but look, Signior Hogrestan! how this ug guittar has hurt my finger.

SP.SPEAKER: Hog.
SP.P: (pressing her inger) O that sweet fair finger!

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: Signior, Signior! you hurt me ten times worse.

SP.SPEAKER: Hog.
SP.P: Oh! such a delightful—Dagran, I feel I am in love—

SP.SPEAKER: Dag.
SP.P: I thought your Honour look'd queerly; but attack her now while your spirits are up.

SP.SPEAKER: Hog.
SP.P: I beg pardon for the seeming impetuosity of my manner—but have you never perceived—

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: What, Signior?

SP.SPEAKER: Hog.
SP.P: (to Dagron) What shall I say, Dagran?

SP.SPEAKER: Dag.
SP.P: Tell her, you mean her love, at once, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Hog.
SP.P: I say, fair maiden, you cannot, I flatter my∣self, be ignorant with how ardent, how tormenting—

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: Bless me, Signior Hogrestan, what's the matter with you? (sings).

SP.SPEAKER: Hog.
SP.P: How long I have suffered!—

SP.SPEAKER: Dag.
SP.P: Yes, ma'am, a most unfortunate wound—

SP.SPEAKER: Hog.
SP.P: S'blood, you'll spoil all! (Cecil sings) I say, sweet lively creature, that I hope—the Baron will sometime hence be brought to—that is, I flatter myself your father will not be against giving his—

SP.SPEAKER: Baron.
SP.P: (within) Daughter, Daughter!

SP.SPEAKER: Dag.
SP.P: Daughter! there's the whole murder out at once.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Baron and Curate.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: Why, daughter, where are you?

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: Here, Sir, at your service.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: Zounds, child! the whole chamber of Am∣sterdam are coming to visit us! We must see that the honours of my family are properly supported.

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.P: Ay, Miss, we must all help to support them.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: Don't you speak, but when you are spoken to, Mr. Curate! I say, child, I expect Mynheer Boter∣ham and his wife here immediately, so you must em∣ploy all your attention to entertain 'em.

SP.SPEAKER: Cer.
SP.P: Lord, Sir, how can I entertain them?

SP.SPEAKER: Hog.
SP.P: (to Dagran) I fear our enterprize will be impeded.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: And they are bringing their son too—a young harum-scarum officer—what shall we do with him?

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: (eagerly) A young officer, papa!—You may depend upon my doing every thing in my power to receive them properly. (Baron and Curate retire) I'll go put on my laylock gown, and look out my new flowers.

SP.SPEAKER: Hog.
SP.P: (melancholy) Then are our flowers withered.

SP.SPEAKER: Dag.
SP.P: And nothing but weeds remaining.

SP.SPEAKER: Hog.
SP.P: (stalking out) I shall have no opportunity of attacking in the van.

SP.SPEAKER: Dag.
SP.P: (stalking after.) Nor I of assisting your honour in the rear. [Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: (advancing with Curate) It's no such thing, Curate! my uncle's fashionable waistcoat was per∣fectly entire the last time I wore it; which, I think, was upon my going to visit Prince Ferdinand of Bruns∣wick, after the battle of Minden.

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.P:
Indeed, Baron, you mistake; I remember the rats devour'd the right flap at the same time as they at up the nosegay, and tore off the hair from your mother's first cousin, who had accidentally fallen upon
her face, from the hook in the wardrobe, where she was hung up because you were ashamed of her.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: What! any of my family, and I ashamed of them?

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.P: Why, Baron, you know she had, in her life time, married a man for love.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: Love! don't talk nonsense to me—have you the confidence to say—

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.P: Yes, if it was the last word I had to say.

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.L: I well recollect the fact,
The waistcoat tore, the slap devour'd;
We caught them just in the act,
Your couz. deflower'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: I tell you, you lie!

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.L: 'Tis true, tho' I die!

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: Then which now must yield the point, say you or I?

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.L: I well recollect the fact, &c.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: How dare you presume to say,
That vermin look for such a treat?

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.L: Alas! Sir, 'twas maigre day,
They'd nought else to eat.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: I'll have your hide so dress'd,

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.L: It is all for the best.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: You're a fool, and an ass, and a knave.

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.L: I'am a tool, and a dog, and a slave.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: How dare you presume to say, &c.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT II.
DIV2.STAGE: Enter the Baron, meeting Mynheer Boterham. Mefrow Boterham, Franzel. Husband and Wife fantastically dressed in Dutch travelling dresses.

SP.SPEAKER: Boterham.
SP.P: WELL, Baron, you see that I and my frow are come as far as from Amsterdam to see you, and to meet my Son, and to pay our compliments, and to look after our money, as our Burgo▪Master says.

SP.SPEAKER: Mef.
SP.P: Yaw, yaw; we have done all this out of pure kindness to you, Baron, and to have an eye to our pro∣perty—as Hubby has told you.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: You are too good, Mynheer Boterham.—I hope you and your wife, and your son, will find no reason to repent of your journey.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: That is impossible, Monsieur le Baron.—A reception so polite—A family so old and so respectable—

SP.SPEAKER: Bot.
SP.P: 'Pshaw! things are not the better for being old, except indeed it may be cheese, and old hock, and old ling, and such like; "as little Fischin the anchovy merchant used to say."

SP.SPEAKER: Mef.
SP.P: (fussaking about) Here's your castle indeed, Baron, seems a little antient or so. Look Deartchee; (to her husband) why don't he take down one part and repair the other with the materials? ha! ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Bot.
SP.P: Very true, Mefrow! Baron, my wife there's a damn'd polite sensible woman, and never laughs, but when she says something good—let me tell you, Baron, she understands what's what!

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: O I have not the least doubt of it! but you will please to recollect, Mynheer, that tho' my castle may be out of repair; yet the antiquity of my family—

SP.SPEAKER: Mef.
SP.P: (coming forward) Won't build it up again, he! he! he! (laughing.)

SP.SPEAKER: Bot.
SP.P: Did not I tell you, Baron, my wife was a damn'd ssiblė woman?

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: But, Sir, allow me to say—

SP.SPEAKER: Bot.
SP.P: You say?—I don't mind any thing that officers say, because you see they affect to be so polite, and all that—they don't quite stick to—you understand me?

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: I hope, Sir, that truth is not inconsistent with good breeding?

SP.SPEAKER: Bot.
SP.P: Good breeding!—It was your mother that made you a soldier; if I had had my will, you should have borne no other arms than I have done all my life; but she could never be satisfied—you understand me, Baron?

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: Upon my word, Mynheer, not altogether, but give me leave to say, that in cases of marriage, a great family—

SP.SPEAKER: Mef.
SP.P: (interrupting) Oh! yes, follows of course: my father (who was a cheese-monger at Leyden) had nineteen children in the first twenty years of his mar∣riage.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: But, Madam, I am speaking of my ancestors; a long train of ancestry, Madam, is—

SP.SPEAKER: Bot.
SP.P: As great an incumbrance as a train of artillery, as my uncle used to say, who drove it in the last war.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: Zounds, Mynheer Boterham, what compari∣sons you are making! Can you possibly forget that the length of my name, the length of my pedigree, the dignity of my family, with an hundred and forty two quarterings in their arms, and a genealogical account for five thousand years back, reflect the highest▪honour! And if I had only been fortunate enough to have had a son—

SP.SPEAKER: Mef.
SP.P: A son, Baron? Zooterkins, where's your daughter? I thought I had not seen every thing—I must go and find Cecil—come along, son—I love to see all and about!—dag!—Baron!—bye Hubb.—Come along son, you shall see all and about too.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: I shall be glad to see the young lady to be sure.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: (After they are gone) Pray, Mynheer Boterham, did you observe on your entrance into the Great Hall, the portrait of a beautiful old lady with a distaff in one hand, and a nosegay in the other?

SP.SPEAKER: Bot.
SP.P: (Musing to himself.) Returns of damaged cheese—discount two and a half per cent.—

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: I say, Mynheer, the lady you were admiring was my grandfather's great aunt.—A notable woman in her time, as the distaff discovers, and fond of the coun∣try as is shewn by the nosegay.

SP.SPEAKER: Bot.
SP.P: (Still musing.) Jews—paper currency—Eng∣lish funds.—

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: Pray, Mynheer, who may you take that pro∣per gentleman-like figure to be?

SP.SPEAKER: Bot.
SP.P: (still the same.) Hope at Amsterdam.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P:
Hope at Amsterdam! Zounds! no such thing! the honour and dignity, and, the—the—of my family
compared to a Dutch banker! Why what the devil are you thinking of, Mynher Boterham?

SP.SPEAKER: Bot.
SP.P: Thinking of! why the little sum I have in your hands—I wish you could be compared to a Dutch banker. I shou'd be glad, if it was conve∣nient—

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: True, Mynheer, you Hollanders give such a good colour to things—

SP.SPEAKER: Bot.
SP.P: But, Baron—I say, that—

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: Yes, there are certainly a great many fine paintings in Holland—but in general, give me leave to say—

SP.SPEAKER: Bot.
SP.P: But I say, Baron, we are wandering from the subject.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: The subjects, as you observe, are too much the same—but then a Dutch landscape is rather uniform.

SP.SPEAKER: Bot.
SP.P: Donder and blixim!—Baron, what are you thinking of? I know nothing of landscapes.—I am talking of land itself. Of that mortgage—

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: Aye, Mynheer Botherham, th only security now a-days; these quarrels of your's with England will never do; no, no, give me a snug mortgage.

SP.SPEAKER: Bot.
SP.P: And give me my money, Baron; why don't you know that I can make seven and a-half per cent▪ in the English funds, and probably, if it's a good distressing year, who knows but the next loan I may make ten?

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: Loan! why would you assist England against your own country, for ten per cent.?

SP.SPEAKER: Bot.
SP.P:
Certainly; why, master Baron, you seem to have no knowledge, no principle of trade about you!
—Did you never step into a counting-house on a post night, as Dirk Doubledown, the broker used to say?

DIV3.HEAD: SONG.

LG.L: Oh! what a life seraphic,
Each day engag'd in traffic!
Seizing what we can for money lent!
Bargains making,
Bargains breaking,
And then strike a balance at cent. per cent.

LG.HEAD: II.
LG.L: Now when the Statesman swaggers,
While Kings are drawing daggers,
Either side to serve we're nothing loth.
England cheating,
France entreating,
Pocket then the stuff, and laugh at both.

LG.HEAD: III.
LG.L: When dead and past all strictures,
Who cares a rush for pictures?
Let me have a purse, not name that's long;
Where's the wonder,
Smoke and donder,
Kinkvervankotsdorspraken, come along.

DIV3.P: [Takes the Baron under the arm, and carries him off.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE, Cecil's Dressing-Room.
DIV3.STAGE: She adjusting herself at the Glass.

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: I shall never get these ugly plaits out of my gown, never—that Grootrump is so careless! but then, poor creature, she has so much to do, that I can't be angry with her—My flowers too are spoil'd with lying by; and then my tucker too, so loose, and so rumpled—Oh! I shall never be fit to appear before a young officer.

SP.SPEAKER: Franzel
SP.P: Pray, Ma'am, don't let us interrupt the young lady, I beg of you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mefrow,
SP.P: Interrupt! zooterkins, I have known her ever since she was the size of a nine-pin;—why I used to bring her sweetmeats at the Convent. Why, child, here's my son say's I don't know you.

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: (turns round and advances) Oh! my dear Madam Boterham—how!—(starts at seeing Franzel)

SP.SPEAKER: Mef.
SP.P: Why, heh! what's the matter now, child? Oh! I suppose you are surpriz'd at my dress. To be sure it is not the newest, but not altogether so un∣fashionable! A little upon the soil or so,—but for travelling—Son, why what's the matter with you? Are you shock'd at your own mother?

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: Me, Madam?—No—Madam—I was—I was—

SP.SPEAKER: Mef.
SP.P: But Cecil—child—

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: Indeed, Madam, I was so surprized, and so pleased, and so rejoiced, and so happy—that—that—

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: Yes, Madam, you see, Madam, the young lady is so surprized, and, that—that—that—Lord—what's the mattter with me? (Aside.)

SP.SPEAKER: Mef.
SP.P: Zooterkins, son! you seem to have lost▪ your senses!—Have not you heard me say a thousand times I was never surprized at any thing?—and did I not tell you the same thing, Cecil, when you were a little chit at the convent! And did not I shew you all and about it?

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: Oh! yes, Madam, I remember very well when you used to come and visit me in your large straw bon∣net and brown jerkin, and the little girls used▪ to look out and say, here comes great Madam Boterham with provisions for the convent.

SP.SPEAKER: Mef.
SP.P: Aye, and what a number of good things I used to say to the fat friar about fasting, ha! ha! ha!

LG.HEAD: I.
LG.L: My friend of St. Francis, if me you'll forgive,
I'll tell you how people in Holland all live;
We eat when we're hungry and drink when we're dry▪
And that's a good thing, my fat friar, says I.

LG.HEAD: II.
LG.L: If we've friends we are happy, content if we've none,
Glad while they are with us, and glad when they're gone;
Rejoiced while they're living, not vex'd when they die,
And that's a good thing, my fat friar, says I.

LG.HEAD: III.
LG.L: When married we're frugal, and cautiously steer,
For usband and wife are inclin'd to be near;
To make both ends meet we continually try,
And that's a good thing, my at friar, says I.

DIV3.P: But come, I have not seen half over the castle, nor the atticks, nor the conveniences below stairs, nor the chapel, nor the stables, nor the Baron's dressing room; and then I must look into the kitchen garden, and see afte my husband, and get myself brushed up a little for sup∣per; and so come along child, and let us see all and about it.
DIV3.STAGE: (Franzel takes hold of Cecil's gown as she is going out, who half turns back, on which he kneels and imme∣diatly begins the following air.)

LG.L: Stop for a moment, charmer,
Listen and do not fear me;
No rude sigh shall alarm her,
Whose smiles alone can chear me:
But should you frown, my fair,
I will fy to despair.
Turn not away, my dearest;
Must he in vain implore thee,
Who's heart is the sincerest,
That ever dar'd adre thee?
But if you frown my fair,
Life is not worth my care.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: Forgive me, for detaining you, Madam, but an involuntary admiration obliges me to—

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: But, Sir, this looks so particular.—Let me follow your mother.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: But one instant—you cannot deny me a moment's audience.—The loveliest of her sex, must be gentle as she is fair.—The graces of her person must be accompanied by tenderness of heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: Ah! Sir, tenderness of heart, they say, is no excuse for impropriety of conduct, and prudence should teach us to guard against its weakness.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: And can the lovely Cecil esteem it either a weakness or an impropriety, to listen to sentiments which the purest passion inspires?

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: Indeed, I am told, I ought not to listen too hastily to such declarations, and I would not wish to fail in my duty.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: Talk not of duty, my charmer, the cold re∣striction of age; tho' tyrant laws may for a while strive to setter our inclinations, the time will come, when na∣ture shall again resume her rights, and all mankind promote the union of te heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: But, Sir, we may be surprized, so let me en∣reat you not to detain me.

DIV3.HEAD: SONG.

LG.L: A thousand reasons all conspire
To drive and hurry me away;
Let go my hand, I must retire,
I cannot, dare not stay.
Ah! shou'd my father enter now,
On your account, he'll force the sigh;
Indeed, I feel, I can't tell how,
And fear, I can't tell why.

DIV3.STAGE: (Exit running.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE, A Passage Room.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Boterham.
DIV3.P: Well, give me a country seat, near Amsterdam, with∣in half a mile of a market. I have not broke my fast since dinner; and I don't see much sign of eating in this house, tho' I have looked pretty narrowly too; as our Domine used to say. But let us take a peep into the old hall.—I think I heard something like a clatter of dishes that way just now. (Going—
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Franzel.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: Sir, permit me to speak a word with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Bot.
SP.P: Ay, but be quick, son, for I am very hungry, and my stomach is not for conversation.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: But, Sir, I have something material to com∣municate.

SP.SPEAKER: Boter.
SP.P: About the supper.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: No, sir; I have been thinking of the subject you have so often mentioned to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Boter.
SP.P: Ay—what of doffing your gew-gaws, and going into trade?

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: No, sir, no; you have often said, that the sooner a young man is settled, the happier he is; and in∣deed, sir, provided the young lady is of a good fa∣mily—

SP.SPEAKER: Boter.
SP.P: A good family! a meer chip in porridge.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: True, sir; but though it may not be the first requisite, yet when joined with beauty—

SP.SPEAKER: Boter.
SP.P: Pa, pa!

SP.SPEAKER: Franz.
SP.P: And good sense—

SP.SPEAKER: Boter.
SP.P: Pence, I believe you mean; yes, yes, a good deal of the pence is very necessary.

SP.SPEAKER: Franz.
SP.P: Possibly, sir, and I flatter myself you can have no objection to my being united—

SP.SPEAKER: Boter.
SP.P: United! married! why, son, you rejoice me, it's the very thing I wish'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Franz.
SP.P: Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Boter.
SP.P: Yes, your mother and I, all the way we came, were drawing it up in our minds, as Nick the Notary used to say.

SP.SPEAKER: Franz.
SP.P: How shall I thank you sufficiently? But who—

SP.SPEAKER: Boter.
SP.P: Who? why I'll tell you. You remember old Beaver the hatter at the Hague?

SP.SPEAKER: Franz.
SP.P: Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Boter.
SP.P: Ay, ay; and you have not forgot his little black-eyed daughter, I dare say, that you used to play with at school, you rogue? A notable girl, let me tell you!

SP.SPEAKER: Franz.
SP.P: But, sir, what then?

SP.SPEAKER: Boter.
SP.P: Why I propose offering you to her father, and trying if we can kick up a match of it, and then you may supply your whole regiment with kevenhullers.

SP.SPEAKER: Franz.
SP.P: But, sir, I beg—

SP.SPEAKER: Boter.
SP.P: Beg! so you would, if you were to keep on that damn'd laced coat. But come; have I hit the nail upon the head, heh! the little hatter's daughter, heh! you young dog, as old 'Zack the Jew used to say.

SP.SPEAKER: Franz.
SP.P: Sir, I had no such thought. My wishes are fix'd upon a lady with ten thousand times her qualifica∣tions.

SP.SPEAKER: Boter.
SP.P: Ha! what! richer?

SP.SPEAKER: Franz.
SP.P: A lady that possesses more—

SP.SPEAKER: Boter.
SP.P: Possesses more?—Aye, there's something in that.

SP.SPEAKER: Franz.
SP.P: More sense, more beauty, more worth, than half the female world united.

SP.SPEAKER: Boter.
SP.P: More worth? What then her father is in a good trade, I suppose?

SP.SPEAKER: Franz.
SP.P: Trade! I mean the lady of this castle, the Baron's daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: Boter.
SP.P: What!

SP.SPEAKER: Franz.
SP.P: Sir, I repeat it; the Baron's daughter, the lovely, innocent Cecil!

SP.SPEAKER: Boter.
SP.P: The innocent Cecil! why, you wicked dog, I hope you have not such a thought. Don't you know that the Baron is not worth a stiver? as poor as a starv'd herring—a fellow with nothing but his pedigree.

SP.SPEAKER: Franz.
SP.P: But, sir, if my mother—

SP.SPEAKER: Boter.
SP.P: Your mother! why does she know any thing? has she seen—

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Mefrow.

SP.SPEAKER: Mef.
SP.P: Well, now, I have seen every thing.

SP.SPEAKER: Boter.
SP.P: Have you? and do you then approve of this—

SP.SPEAKER: Mef.
SP.P: O, no; never saw any thing like it in my life.

SP.SPEAKER: Boter.
SP.P: There, son! I thought your mother could not think of such a preposterous affair.

SP.SPEAKER: Franz.
SP.P: But, sir, you mistake—my mother as yet does not comprehend.

SP.SPEAKER: Mef.
SP.P: Zooterkins, hubby! what preposterous affair are you talking about? I was speaking of the old castle here.

SP.SPEAKER: Boter.
SP.P: Pa, pa! and your son wishes to bury our money under the ruins of it. He wants to marry the Baron's daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: Mef.
SP.P: Zooterkins, yaw!

SP.SPEAKER: Boter.
SP.P: Yaw donder, yaw—

SP.SPEAKER: Franz.
SP.P: Can any thing be more natural, madam, than that I should esteem a young lady whom you have been partial to from infancy?

SP.SPEAKER: Mef.
SP.P: Why to be sure, hubb, she is a sweet chit; and if son must marry, why Cecil's a woman, and a woman's a wife—and that's all and about it.

SP.SPEAKER: Boter.
SP.P: Well, my frow, I always said you knew what's what.—(Bell rings)—Gadstedlikins, there's the supper, away with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Franz.
SP.P: Think, sir, of the happiness I shall enjoy.

SP.SPEAKER: Boter.
SP.P: (in a hurry to go) Yes, yes; the supper, the supper.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: (to his mother) Pray speak a word for m.

SP.SPEAKER: Mef.
SP.P: (pulling him out) Don't you see your father is sharp set? this is not a time to soften him.

SP.SPEAKER: Franz.
SP.P: (to his father) Consider, sir, my future peace.—(Bell)

SP.SPEAKER: Bot.
SP.P: Zounds! make haste, or we shan't have a piece left. [Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Franz.
SP.P: (to his mother) For Heaven's sake! assist me, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Mef.
SP.P: Very well, son; first we'll go in, and then we'll go out and then we'll see all and about it.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE, An old Hall.
DIV3.STAGE: Variety of Pictures hung round the Room; a Table and Supper, with Wine, Glasses, &c.
Enter Baron, Hogrestan, and Cecil, at one Door, Dagran and Grootrump with Dishes at another.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: Come, come; quick, quick with that supper, there; and take care you don't overset each other; but where the devil is the middle dish, heh! What! you you hav'nt forgot that, I hope?

SP.SPEAKER: Groot.
SP.P: No, Sir, no; the curate is bringing it up stairs as fast as he can.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Curate, with a large Boar's Head, carrying it with difficulty.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: Umph! you lazy creature, what makes you so long! you are generally forward enough when any thing is to be eat.

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.P: (setting the dish on the table) Why, what a head is this for a body to carry? I can scarce stand under it.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: I wish you carried half so good a one of your own. But come, where's Mynheer Boterham, and his wife, and the officer gone to?

SP.SPEAKER: Hog.
SP.P: To the devil, I hope. (aside)—O fury! here they are.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Boterham, Mefrow, and Franzel.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: I was afraid, Mynheer Boterham, you had forgot my supper time.

SP.SPEAKER: Bot.
SP.P: Not I, in good troth; for I have been talking of it ever since dinner, have not I, son?

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: Indeed, Sir, I believe it has been uppermost in your thoughts.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: Come, gentlemen, let us be seated: Madam Boterham, the honour of your fair hand.
SP.STAGE: [Leads her to the table, and places her.

SP.SPEAKER: Hog.
SP.P: (to Cecil) Sweet creature! the felicity of yours—

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: (giving her hand to Franzel.) There's no oc∣casion to trouble yourself, Signior.

DIV3.STAGE: [They all seat themselves. Hogrestan sulky seating himself opposite.

SP.SPEAKER: Hog.
SP.P: What coxcombs the military are now a-days!

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: We don't look quite so well as we shou'd do, Mefrow; so I hope you will excuse appearances.

SP.SPEAKER: Mef.
SP.P: Yaw, yaw; nobody minds appearances in Holland.

SP.SPEAKER: Hog.
SP.P: I see that plain enough!

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: Mynheer, I know you love old cheese; there's a piece near you has been doing duty in the family for some months, and hard duty too.

SP.SPEAKER: Bot.
SP.P:
Aye! yet it does not seem much the worse for it; I think I could do its business in two attacks. But,
Baron! snick or snee! here's a head as large as the head of a man of war! What a huge thing it is!

SP.SPEAKER: Mef.
SP.P: Then let me undertake it, hubby, I can ma∣nage it, I warrant you. (pulls the dish towards her.)

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: Come, Mr. Curate, what are you about? Why don't you do the honours of my Castle, and shew the pictures while we sup?

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.P: What! before I sup myself?

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: The Czar of Muscovy never repeated his orders twice.

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.P: Oh! very well, better luck another time. (getting up with his knife and fork) There, ladies and gentlemen, you shall see the potrait of Charles, surnamed the Black, from his bushy beard. One that would ut up whole nations while other people were eating their supper. A powerful man in his day, and a great favourite with the ladies.

SP.SPEAKER: Hog.
SP.P: (surlily, looking at Franzel) There's n great merit in that; the ladies favourites have often little to recommend them.

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.P: There you see the Baroness Buckskinsbone; a famous huntress; and there's the portrait of the old Duke of▪ Whartenwisker, who was hang'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: How!

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.P: I mean who hang'd his confessor for telling secrets. A poor priest who had not a cross to bless himself with, a merry dog tho', and laugh'd at every thing.

SP.SPEAKER: Mef.
SP.P: Why that Curate seems a pretty jolly kind of ellow; he wou'd make his fortune at one of our fairs.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: Ah! he's as sleepy as an old cat.

SP.SPEAKER: Bot.
SP.P: I think you treat him more like a dog.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: And a sad dog he is—but, come, here's my old toast, (fill a bumper) I always drink it with my daughter. "Here's the antient gentlemen over the chimney, at the bottom of the tree, the great root of our family, Baron Hockinbergerbanderboskibus."

SP.SPEAKER: Bot.
SP.P: Boskibus! Gadstedlikins! what a name!—I like a shorter toast, for my part, heh! Mynheer Ho∣grestan, what say you?

SP.SPEAKER: Hog.
SP.P: (looking at the lovers, who are engaged) Umph! I like nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.P: And I should like something—I believe I may sit down to supper again now, eh, Baron?

SP.SPEAKER: Bot.
SP.P: Ay, do my little curate, let's be merry.—Come, Baron, if you please, I'll give you a song in our way—a great favourite at the Stock-fish club, and very melodious; but you must all assist me to make a noise.

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.P: Yes, we'll all assist, and make noise enough.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: I wish you wou'd desist, and be silent. King Stanislaus never permitted his vassals to speak—

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.P: But, I suppose he permitted them to eat, tho'.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: Now, Mynheer, your song, and then to bed.

DIV3.HEAD: SONG.

LG.L: Some men women, some men wine,
Some men wit bewilders;
Nothing can make me repine,
So I have store of guilders.
Silvertie, guildertie, money galore, ducats, doubloons, and guilders.

SP.SPEAKER: Chorus.
SP.L: Silvertie, guildertie, &c.

LG.L: Some love brandy, some love rum,
Some Batavi'! arrack-o!
Let me have, where e'r I come,
Pipes and good tobacco.
Smokertie, jokertie, all in a cloud, liquor, and good tobacco.
Smokertie, jokertie, &c.
Some folks slight us, some folks scold,
What care I for such men?
Whether we are bought or sold,
It's all alike to Dutchmen.
Pocketie, knocketie, all the same thing, nothing's amiss to Dutchmen.
Pocketie, knocketie, &c.

DIV3.STAGE: [Exeunt.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE, A Passage.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Dagran with a Night Gown, Fur Cap, Boot∣jack, &c. Hogrestan following, and musing.

SP.SPEAKER: Hog.
SP.P: For the rest, I am determined—

SP.SPEAKER: Dag.
SP.P: Yes, your Honour, now for rest after the fatigues of the day. Your things are all ready, and you may go to bed immediately.

SP.SPEAKER: Hog.
SP.P: (musing) But what boots it to think—

SP.SPEAKER: Dag.
SP.P: Wou'd your Honour chuse your boots off here, or step into your own room?

SP.SPEAKER: Hog.
SP.P: I shall not chuse them off at all.

SP.SPEAKER: Dag.
SP.P: Why sure you can't mean to take them to bed with you, as you used to do in the campaign?

SP.SPEAKER: Hog.
SP.P: To bed, Dagran—I may possibly never go there again.

SP.SPEAKER: Dag.
SP.P: Heav'n forbid, your Honour, you may as well be bedridden all the rest of your life.

SP.SPEAKER: Hog.
SP.P: Thou know'st how easily I take offence?

SP.SPEAKER: Dag.
SP.P: Perfectly, your Honour.

SP.SPEAKER: Hog.
SP.P: And thou rememberest how severely I handled a certain cavalier's nose, who once look'd oddly at me?

SP.SPEAKER: Dag.
SP.P: Yes, because he had the misfortune to squint.

SP.SPEAKER: Hog.
SP.P: None of thy jokes, good Dagran—What then must I feel, when I have the misfortune not to be look'd at at all?—to have my passion nipt in the very bud—to be hurt in the tenderest part?

SP.SPEAKER: Dag.
SP.P: What in your Honour's wound here? (point∣ing to his side).

SP.SPEAKER: Hog.
SP.P: (putting his hand to his heart) No! here! here! here!—but I have a remedy in my pocket. (Pulling out a long pistol)

SP.SPEAKER: Dag.
SP.P: A very desperate one, indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: Hog.
SP.P: And that audacious modern sprig, who of∣fended my sight all supper time, shall give me satis∣faction.

SP.SPEAKER: Dag.
SP.P: He seems to have given too much satisfaction already.

SP.SPEAKER: Hog.
SP.P: His joy shall be short-lived, for thou shalt instanly summon him to meet me this night.

SP.SPEAKER: Dag.
SP.P: And fight across a lanthorn.

SP.SPEAKER: Hog.
SP.P: No; hold—to-morrow will do; mean time I'll take a cool walk in the garden, and practise my aim by moon-light. [Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Dag.
SP.P: Ah! then I shall miss my aim with poor Grootrump. [Exit.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE, An old Gallery hung with Pictures—An Iron Sconce hanging in the Middle, with one Candle. A large Press at the further End.—Several Chamber Doors that open into it.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Baron, Cecil, and Curate with two Candles.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: Well, child, you have had trouble enough with this Dutchman and his coxcomical son—you may retire to your chamber.

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: (comes forward to her Apartment near the front of the stage.) Ah! I know not how it is, I never felt myself less inclin'd to sleep in my life. (Goes int her room.)

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: Now, master Curate, you may go to bed, tho' you have been asleep all day long.

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.P: Pray, Baron, what bed am I to lie in? has not the young officer got mine?

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: What then? here's the key of the old clothes press; tuck yourself up there, among the garments of my ancestors.

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.P: (going, and opening the folding doors.) Lord have mercy! one might as well be tucked up in re∣ality.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: Come, no muttering; did not my own god∣father, the Bishop of Gottingen, sleep in a stable by choice? [Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.P: Aye! he was a Bishop; no wonder he was fond of a stall; but as I am only a poor curate, why I shou'd be content with a bedchamber and a candle? Well, now to get up a little in the world, (gets into the clothes press)—A snug situation this—some of my brethern, indeed, are never content (adjusting himself in the old cloaths)—Well, plague on all the ambitious say I,—I wish—aye—I wish 'em a good night! (shuts the door).

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Franzel, his Dress a little disordered.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P:
Bless me! how dismal is this old castle, es∣pecially to a mind disturbed; and every thing so dark, I shall scarce be able to find my own apartment!—
Hah! what piece of antique furniture is this? (feeling the press)—aye, some repository, I suppose, where the Baron locks up the family incumbrances—well, let it rest! and now for my own repose, if my anxious heart will permit me to enjoy any.—Aye, this is my father's room, this the Baron's; and this, this must be the chamber which I was told they had allotted for me.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE, An old Garden, with a Moat and a View of the Castle, with Miss Cecil's Chamber Window.—Hogrestan and Dagran watching under it.

SP.SPEAKER: Hogrestan.
SP.P: I Could look at that window all day long.

SP.SPEAKER: Dag.
SP.P: Why we have look'd at it all night.

SP.SPEAKER: Hog.
SP.P: Ah, Dagran! that is the chamber of the lovely Cecil. Sweet maid! how gentle are her man∣ners, how innocent are her employments!

SP.SPEAKER: Dag.
SP.P: To be sure, your honour, she is fast asleep.

SP.SPEAKER: Hog.
SP.P: True! in all probability she is now lost in the sweet arms of repose.

SP.SPEAKER: Dag.
SP.P: And here stand we broad awake, and half starved to death.

SP.SPEAKER: Hog.
SP.P: Or possibly, Dagran, not inclined to rest, she is now turning over some new page, gaining fresh in∣struction and receiving new light.

SP.SPEAKER: Dag.
SP.P: Why, your honour, there seems to have been a light in the room some time—(the candle is seen to move)—and now it fts.

SP.SPEAKER: Hog.
SP.P: Ha! what say'st thou? Ay, my sweet Ce∣cil is rising, I suppose to her morning's devotion.

SP.SPEAKER: Dag.
SP.P: She is a good creature—(starts)—Lord bless us!

SP.SPEAKER: Hog.
SP.P: Ha! why, what—wh—wh—what's the mat∣ter?

SP.SPEAKER: Dag.
SP.P: As I'm a Christian, your honour, there's a man in Miss Cecil's chamber.

SP.SPEAKER: Hog.
SP.P: (seizing him by the collar) Why rascal! vil∣lain! scoundrel!

DIV3.STAGE: (Window opens; Franzel looks out, and closes it again.)

SP.SPEAKER: Dag.
SP.P: There he is before your very eyes.

SP.SPEAKER: Hog.
SP.P: Heavens!

SP.SPEAKER: Dag.
SP.P: Thank heaven, I'm as happy as a prince.

SP.SPEAKER: Hog.
SP.P: At what?

SP.SPEAKER: Dag.
SP.P: That your honour will believe me another time.

SP.SPEAKER: Hog.
SP.P: (walking about) A man in Miss Cecil's cham∣ber!—do I live? am I awake? do I see?

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Curate—they run against each other.

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.P: No, if you did you would not run against me.

SP.SPEAKER: Dag.
SP.P: Why, your honour, we are attack'd on all sides.

SP.SPEAKER: Hog.
SP.P: Such a misfortune, such an unlook'd-for dis∣grace!

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.P: 'Psha! Monsieur Hogrestan, don't take it s much to heart; you ran against me, I ran against you, and the thing was an accident, and it's all for the best.

SP.SPEAKER: Hog.
SP.P: (still walking about) And then to pass the night in so envied a situation!

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.P: What I?

SP.SPEAKER: Hog.
SP.P: He must certainly have spent the whole of it in Miss Cecil's apartment.

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.P: Heaven bless you! I spent it in the old clothes press.

SP.SPEAKER: Hog.
SP.P: (to Dagran.) It must have been the young of∣ficer, Dagran, that we saw looking out of Miss Cecil's window.

SP.SPEAKER: Dag.
SP.P: Yes, your honour, I dare say it was not an old one.

SP.SPEAKER: Hog.
SP.P: Come then, march, we must prepare for the attack, and summon the garrison to surrender. [Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Dag.
SP.P: Certainly—or we may leave the enemy in possession. [Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.P: (alone) The young officer peeping out of Miss Cecil's window!—so, so—but it's all for the best.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE, A Breakfast Room.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Boterham and Mefrow.

SP.SPEAKER: Boter.
SP.P: Well, my frow, you know I told you last night you would have things your own way.

SP.SPEAKER: Mef.
SP.P: And ar'n't they always best? So what sig∣nifies talking? Let us tell the Baron of it at once, and son shall take Cecil along with him to Amsterdam, and do every thing the same as we do.

SP.SPEAKER: Boter.
SP.P: Why to be sure, Deartche, tho' it's a great deal of money to throw away upon this old castle; and then to give up the little hatter, for a poor fellow worth nothing but his pictures—but—

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Baron.

SP.SPEAKER: Mef.
SP.P: Lord, Baron, my husband was just talking of you.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: Mynheer Boterham, I thank you; you are always thinking of your friends.

SP.SPEAKER: Boter.
SP.P: So I was, Baron—so I was, and I'll give you a proof of it—for I've an intention of granting you a great favour.

SP.SPEAKER: Mef.
SP.P: Stop, hubby! let me grant it him—So, Ba∣ron, you must know we have an idea—

SP.SPEAKER: Boter.
SP.P: But, Deartchre, the Baron will be sensible of the favour, without being so particular—to be sure, giving up the little hatter at the Hague is a goodly sa∣crifice, as Thrum the Parson used to say.

SP.SPEAKER: Mef.
SP.P: For a few old pictures and a tumble-down castle—but I hate mentioning obligations.

SP.SPEAKER: Boter.
SP.P: And then the reversion of his cousin, Old Pledge, the pawnbroker's goods at Rotterdam, all lost, perhaps, for a miserable barony.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: I confess, Mynheer Boterham, I don't com∣prehend the force of what you are talking about.

SP.SPEAKER: Mef.
SP.P: Lord, Baron, how should you? for we have not yet named the favour we intend you; but hubby will inform you how and about it.

SP.SPEAKER: Boter.
SP.P: Why then to tell you the truth, Baron, my son has conceived a disagreeable kind of affection for your daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: How!

SP.SPEAKER: Boter.
SP.P: Yes, Baron, I see you are overjoyed, and therefore, in one word, as my wife desires it, and my son wishes it, I have given my consent; and they shall be married at fight, without any grace.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: Married! what, your son, Mynheer Boter∣ham, marry my daughter!

SP.SPEAKER: Bot.
SP.P:
Ay, and very thankful, I dare say you are, and
to be sure you ought to be—Why do you know I have given up the Prince of Orange's hatter at the Hague, and his only child, a tight little wench, with a good stock of—

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: Assurance, I think! a hatter at the Hague!—Have you forgot you are now addressing yourself to the head of the Kinkervankotsdorsprakingatchderns family?

SP.SPEAKER: Boter.
SP.P: And the sooner they change that damn'd name the better. But pray what is your reason for he∣sitating?

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: Reason! reason! heavens! five thousand!—there, Mynheer—there, Mefrow, (shewing pictures) the plainest in the world.

SP.SPEAKER: Mef.
SP.P: Yes, provided the dust was rubbed off them.

SP.SPEAKER: Boter.
SP.P: What, Baron, would you keep your daughter single for a parcel of old pictures, fit for nothing but to throw into a bonfire, to rejoice with for having got rid of them?

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: Zounds, I—but hold—my great uncle, the Duke of Wolfenbuttle, used to say, the rights of hospitality protect even impertinence.

SP.SPEAKER: Boter.
SP.P: And my cousin Scrip, the attorney, used to reply, it would be better if every body paid their debts.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: Low insinuation! I have only to beg you will instantly leave my castle.

SP.SPEAKER: Mef.
SP.P: For fear it should fall about our ears.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Franzel and Cecil.
DIV3.P: Oh, son, you are just come in time to be going.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: The insufferable insults of low-bred people!

SP.SPEAKER: Boter.
SP.P: The pride of some folks, not worth a doit, without capital enough even to set up for a beggar!

SP.SPEAKER: Franz.
SP.P: (to his father, who is going.) Think, sir, how my heart is torn!

SP.SPEAKER: Boter.
SP.P: Away to Holland; there you'll have no oc∣casion for any heart at all. [Exit Boter▪ and Franz.

SP.SPEAKER: Mef.
SP.P: Zooterkin, I'm in such a fidget! Bye, Ce∣il. Well, I always thought your great German folks had little to boast of. Give me a Dutch hottom after all. [Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Cecil.
SP.P: (to Mefrow, following) But madam—madam Boterham—

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: (running after her.) Hold, child! what are you about?—Your maiden aunt, Dorothea—

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: But politeness, sir, affection—

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
