SP.P: I say she had neither—She knew how to comport herself properly, and died in a respectable state of virginity, rather than contaminate the honour of her house by marrying a—But come, madam, to th tower-room; let us try whether a little confinement will not cool your courage—Fifty years ago your aunt Barbara was shut up in the same apartment. So away, and suffer and repent as your anceste have done before you. [Exit Cecil.
Heralds and Cap of Maintenance, I will support every syllable of my name, or die in pronouncing it.

LG.L: Shall lineage, older than the Flood,
On dunghill Dutchman fix?
Shall high descent, and German blood,
With gin and butter mix?
Shall Holstenhausen, honour'd name!
Shall Womberg, Schomberg, lose their fame,
In Vanders and Mynheers?
Renown,
Let down,
What matters whence my birth I draw,
What boots it that the great Nassau
Is link'd among my peers?
When Nature's systems alter'd are,
When Princes herd with swine,
The Hogen-Mogens then may dare
To blend their arms with mine.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Hogrestan and Curate, hastily.

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.P: Baron, Baron! they are just set off.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: I know it.

SP.SPEAKER: Hog.
SP.P: O, Baron, such a story!

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: Zounds! I know it.

SP.SPEAKER: Hog.
SP.P: What, though transacted in her own apart∣ment!

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.P: (grinning) Hoh, hoh!

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: Ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Hog.
SP.P: That the angelic Cecil should be prevailed on to consent!

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: How! my daughter prevailed on to do what? I hope—

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.P: Ay, but it's too late.

SP.SPEAKER: Hog.
SP.P: That, forgetting the antiquity of her family, she should descend to a low plebeian.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P:
Ah! I see it all—I feel my disgrace—Un∣worthy
girl, to sink herself to a union with a base-born Dutchman! A private marriage too!

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.P: I wish it was; he! he! he! for then I should have had a finger in the pye. [Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Hog.
SP.P: Do not deceive yourself, Baron—but know that, without that title, the young officer who is just gone, passed the whole of last night in your daughter's apartment.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: (laying his hand on Hogrestan's shoulder) Umph! not married then!

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: No!

SP.SPEAKER: Hog.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: Signior Hogrestan, I thank you. When my great grandmother▪ Dinah of Castile, gave the Count O'Richter a slap on the face at the court of Brunswick, the Count turned about and said, Madam, I am glad it's no worse. [Exit, leaning on Hogrestan.

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.P: Ho, ho! "I'm glad it's no worse!"—Ecod I find this business then is really all for the best. [Exit.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE, The Baron's Gallery, with only one Window, and all hung round with Pictures.

SP.SPEAKER: Cecil.
SP.P: (coming forward with a letter she has just written) What, shall a ridiculous pride of family force us to forego every natural affection? No. If I can but convey this letter to Franzel, he shall still find I am his only—But hold! am I not passing the bounds which form has prescribed to our sex?—Ah Love, 'tis you who must blot out the errors you occasion, and forgive the confidence you inspire.

LG.L: Come, fierce invader, parent of anguish,
Let not thy victim unheeded languish;
Banish despair, health's roses consuming,
And in my bosom plant hope ever blooming;
Bid expectation chace all past sorrow,
Sooth the sad present, and whisper to-morrow.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Curate, with a faggot under his arm.

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.P: I beg pardon, madam Cecil; but just took the liberty of seeing whether you wanted any fire.—Ha! ha! ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: Curate, will you do me a favour?

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.P: Lord bless me!—I—(aside)—To be sure, miss, any thing in my power.

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: 'Twill give me the most unspeakable satis∣faction.

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.P: Ha! will it? You may depend upon me, miss—I may as well lay down my sticks. (Aside) Well, miss! (rubbing his hands)

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: You know how violent my father is.

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.P: Don't mind him; he'll never find us out, I as∣sure you.

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: True, if you're cautious, he cannot discover it; at least 'till it is too late.

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.P: Oh, Miss, you may rely upon me.

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: Then do me the favour of carrying this letter to Mr. Franzel.

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.P: Bless us!—I thought—but it's well it's no worse!

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: You will find him at the inn, I dare say; or somewhere hereabouts—tell him not to fail being at the place I have appointed.

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.P: Lord, Miss! I can deny you nothing! so you shall see how well I'll execute the business—there—there—snug's the word, (putting the letter into his pocket) I think the old Baron won't easily find this out—he! he! he!—Nor my great grandmother, Dinah of Castile, neither!—he! he! he!

DIV3.STAGE: Enter the Baron behind, slaps the Curate on the Shoulder.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: Dinah of Castile!—Why what's that you were cramming into your pocket so hastily?

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.P: Nothing, Baron!—no—no—thing, I as∣sure you!

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: Remember who I am!—and speak the truth.

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: Indeed the Curate was only going—that is coming to—

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: Hold your tongue, Cecil!—I am now con∣vinc'd there is mischief hatching against the honour of my family! and have you the confidence to be trea∣sonable and rebellious in my own house? Do you want to seduce my daughter?

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.P: I seduce her!—Lord, Baron! I am as innocent as—

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: Don't insult me with innocence—but if yo expect my countenance—

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.P: Countenance!

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: Yes, if you ever wish to have a good living, confess! Has not my daughter given you some letter?

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.P: And ou promise a good living, do you?

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: Aye! or perhaps a deanery or a bishoprick.

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.P: Really! Will you promise a—

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: Zounds! I'll promise any thing—

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.P: Dear Miss, I feel myself a going—well then, as you have promis'd, th—th—th—there—is the letter, and I hope—

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: (snatching it, sees the direction) Despair! what's here? (running over the letter) "Nothing shall separate us—father's cruelty—escape if you remain about the House—to be join'd for ever."—Degenerate child!—and you, you ungracious dog, after all my civil treatment of you! but get out of my house.

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.P: Out of your house! where's the bishop∣rick?

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: Begone! or I'll break every bone in your skin!

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.P: But, your promise—

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: My denial!

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.P: A good living!

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: A good beating!—zounds! get out of my house! you shall have no living here.

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.P: That I see plain enòugh—stay and starve—budge and be merry—so it's all for the best.

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: (with warmth) But, Sir, allow me to say—

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: I'll not allow you to say any thing!—do but look at the faces of your venerable family! they never—

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Hogrestan.

SP.SPEAKER: Hog.
SP.P: Well, Baron! so you have turn'd the curate out of doors? I'am glad of it; and Miss, too, I see, begins to be sensible of the impropriety of her choice.

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: How!

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: Aye!—had she indeed, like one of her great grandmothers, who was lineally descended from the Ap-Goats, the most numerous family in all Wales, fixed her affections on a gentleman with some fifty quarter∣ings in his arms, I would have forgiven his poverty.

SP.SPEAKER: Hog.
SP.P: Or allowing that the gentleman had been fomewhat advanced in life.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: Aye, if he had been an hundred.

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: (aside) Heavens!

SP.SPEAKER: Hog.
SP.P: Or that his person had not been so favour∣able.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: I could have forgiven her on that point, had it been yourself, Signior Hogrestan!

SP.SPEAKER: Hog.
SP.P: (astonished) Baron, you rejoice me!—and I am the more happy at the event, as it emboldens me to say, that I have long entertained a secret passion for Madam Cecil—

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: I beg, Sir, that it may be mentioned no more.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: And I beg that it may!—Signior Hogrestan, give me your hand; you shall marry Cecil this afternoon; I'll shew her that I at least can behave like an affection∣ate parent.

SP.SPEAKER: Hog.
SP.P:
Say no more, Baron; I think not of what has happened in this family;—I wish now, I had not
call'd out that base-born officer, as I must spill his blood!

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: His blood! trust me, Signior, 'twould but sully your sword.

SP.SPEAKER: Hog.
SP.P: But my courage—

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: Don't think of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Hog.
SP.P: My character!

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: Not worth notice.

SP.SPEAKER: Hog.
SP.P: My delicacy!

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: You shock me to hear you talk so.

SP.SPEAKER: Hog.
SP.P: He may presume—

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: He! Charles the Fifth to a chimney sweeper!—but that ungracious slut! I'll never forgive her. (look∣ing at his daughter.)

SP.SPEAKER: Hog.
SP.P: Pray, Baron, spare your danghter, as we are to be united.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: Come then, we'll leave her to prepare herself, for she shall be made happy, tho' it's ever so little.

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P:
To what a situation am I reduced! Unkind ancestors as you are, to you it is owing that the last of your descendants is thus wretched. [Retires to the back of the stage, and sitting down on an old pair of steps placed for the purpose of cleaning the pictures.]—But, let me consider for a moment, and try if I cannot yet devise some method of extricating myself from this horrid abode. (Musing)—I have it! Exalted worthies, grandams, great-grandams, aunts, and cousins, you shall for once descend from your high stations to assist my humble views.—Come, my prim old lady, for the first time, be engaged in a love affair; and you, my dear cardinal, be so kind as to
conceal her blushes; (throws it on the other pictures) down with you, priests, generals, and counsellors; lay all your heads together for my sake; no quarrelling about precedence now, for I'll adjust the ceremonials.—Come along—the quicker the better.
SP.STAGE: [Scene closes while she is piling the pictures.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE, A Wood.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Curate, with a Bundle of Clothes on his Back.
He throws them down on his coming on the Stage.

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.P: Well, here am I! as fatigued as if I had still got the Old Baron upon my back, tho' thank heaven I am now somewhat lighter; (sitting down on a bundle) Ah! service is no inheritance, that's certain, a gentle∣man may moil, and rub about, kill pigs, and clean knives, and lay table cloths, and brush clothes, and nobody think a bit the better of him for it—no—no.—I'll give up this way of living industrious—I'll get into a good curacy of twenty pounds a year, with some little duty at three or four parishes, and be as idle as the fattest of them all.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Franzel.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: My dear friend, I rejoice to see you.

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.P: And my dear enemy, I thank you.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: Pray, Curate, how have I deserv'd that ap∣pellation?

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.P: Because—because—I am much obliged to you without your knowing it—in short, you have turn'd me out of the Baron's service, and have made me a gentle∣man at large.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: Explain yourself.

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.P: Why then, in plain language, young Sir, I was got into Madam Cecil's apartment, and the Baron came in suddenly, and caught me in the very fact.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: What!

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.P: Of bringing you a letter from her.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: S'blood! then why don't you give it me in∣stantly? I am distracted with expectation.

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.P: Give it you!—because—the truth is—that said letter is in the Baron's coat pocket.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: Heavens! am I then to be continually disap∣pointed, and to have my hopes raised only to fall the lower!

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.P: Come, come; don't take it so to heart; I believe I can recollect some part of the letter—let's see—(repeating)—"Father's cruelty,"—ay, that's true enough—"pride of family,"—ay, the old story—"escape."

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: Escape!—how?—where—when?—

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.P: Why, I believe she said, that if you cou'd contrive to wait under the Tower window—

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: The Tower window! why that's the very place I am going to meet Hogrestan, by his own ap∣pointment.

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.P: Is it so? then you may kill two birds with one stone.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: I'll fly to preserve one of them; so, Cu∣rate, I wish you a good morning.

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.P: Is that all? As short as one of my own ser∣mons; but heark'ye, Mr. Scapegrace, a word with you, if you please.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: Any other time, my good friend, but at pre∣sent I am so press'd—

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.P: You are going upon an errand where a gentle∣man of my coat may be of service; in your present expedition, I take it, you'll either get married, or run thro' the body; no matter which, as I can be useful to you in both calamities.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: Ay, you're a wag; but marry or bury, there's nothing like carrying a pleasant countenance, so come along, Master Curate.

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.P: Tie up, or cover up, it's all for the best.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE, The Baron's Gallery, with the Pictures taken down, and piled in a Heap under the Window; Cecil out of the Window.

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: Well, thank Heaven, and my kind aunts and uncles, I am now got to the top of my wishes; how charming is the return of liberty to the captive! then let me not lose a moment; good bye to you, my noble ancestors; but I will not be ungrateful, 'tis to you I owe my hopes of future happiness, and my boast hence∣forth shall be to have sprung from you. [Disappears.

DIV3.STAGE: Baron, unlocking the Door.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P:
Sure, I heard some noise here!—hey day! what the devil's all this?—why, daughter—Cecil!—child, where are you?—my pictures too—all turn'd topsy-turvy—no order—no precedence, and here's my
great, great grandmother Gertrude upon the ground, and in what a condition! The window open—oh, I see it all; Cecil has had the audacity to trample upon her ancestors, and fly from them without any remorse. Oh! my pictures, my daughter, my pictures!—oh! oh! (Runs about the stage with the picture in his hand.)

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Hogrestan, with sword drawn, Dagran follow∣ing.

SP.SPEAKER: Hog.
SP.P: O Baron, Baron!—I have seen the whole.

SP.SPEAKER: Dag.
SP.P: And I the half.

SP.SPEAKER: Hog.
SP.P: (pointing to his sword) My rival has escaped me! So, Baron, here it is, unsullied and without a flaw.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: (pointing to the picture) Without a flaw! What d'ye call this—is this a proper condition for a lady?

SP.SPEAKER: Dag.
SP.P: We have just left another in a worse.

SP.SPEAKER: Hog.
SP.P: Ay, Baron, what signifies looking at one old picture out of its place—

SP.SPEAKER: Dag.
SP.P: (turning about) When one may look at a hundred in the same situation.

SP.SPEAKER: Hog.
SP.P: (seeing the pile) Love and madness—that I should be just in time to see her run away!

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: And that I should be just too late to prevent it!

SP.SPEAKER: Dag.
SP.P: And that I should be betwixt both, and able to do nothing!

SP.SPEAKER: Hog.
SP.P: Perdition! but, Baron, let us not waste time—she cannot have escaped long. Let us pursue her.

SP.SPEAKER: Hog.
SP.P: True! let us follow immediately, and snatch her, if possible, from love and destruction. (Exeunt.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE, The Road.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Curate, running across the stage.

SP.SPEAKER: Curate.
SP.P: Oh, how lightly one treads in pursuing a good action, especially when one does it out of spite! To be sure, the Baron will be so angry with me—but then who cares for it?—"I have married your daughter to Capt. Franzel," says I. You wretch, says he, dow durst you presume to ally my undutiful daugh∣ter with that dog! "Lord! Baron," says I, "it's because 'tis my duty to do it." To have the assurance, says he, to put a stop to the honor of my family! "Why," says I, "it is the only way to encrease it." Then, says he again, my uncle, the Duke of Hogstye—my aunt Flabigastiberg—my great grandfather—"And now," says I, "you'll be a grandfather your∣self"—Zounds! you dog, I'll break every bone in your skin. "Heytitity," says I,—Oh no! I could never say any thing to that in my life.—After all, what have I lost by quitting the Baron? Some excel∣lent abusive words, intermixed with a few blows; a charming plenty of work, and a good scarcity of meat; various opportunities of activity in the day-time, and a night's rest in an old clothes press.

LG.L: When I think
What meat and drink,
Store of labour and little chink,
Combing wigs,
Killing pigs,
Fretting here,
Sweating there,
Up in the garret, without any bed,
Down in the kitchen, without any bread,
Happy to be
From bondage free,
I whip out my bottle and merrily quaff;
Roar and quaff,
And titter and laugh.
But when sorrow
Bids good morrow,
Nought to lend, and nothing to borrow,
Out of heart, and out of place,
All my chattels before my face;
When my bundle
Thus I trundle,
No shelter nigh,
But clouds and sky,
I pocket my bottle and sadly sigh,
Sob and sigh,
And snivel and cry.
Then again, when aching bones
ut me in mind of former groans;
When I think of the blows I have borne so oft,
Kick'd into the cellar, quite down from the loft,
The loss of my place
Is no such disgrace;
So I'll strive to sleep,
And my cares beguile;
For my poverty weep,
For my consequence smile;
Work no more,
But sleep and snore,
'Till tickled with fancy, up I prance;
I kick my heels, and take a dance;
One, two, three,
Tol lol der lol de;
Quaff and dance,
Roar and prance,
Dance and prance, not sob and sigh;
Roar and quaff, not snivel and cry;
Not bawl and blubber, but sing and quaff;
Not snivel, but titter, and dance, and laugh.
Fal de rol, &c. [Exit.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE the Last, a beautiful Meadow, Church at a Distance.
DIV3.STAGE: Franzel leading Cecil down the Stage.

SP.SPEAKER: Franz.
SP.P: Well, my charming Cecil, thanks to your love and resolution, we are now beyond the reach of disappointment; even your father's resentment will re∣spect the sacred rites that unite us.

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: Indeed, my Franzel, I am certain I shall never have the courage to meet his anger—that devoted at∣tachment to family—

SP.SPEAKER: Franz.
SP.P:
Family! my angel, believe me, there is no
one respects illustrious lineage or the just pride of family more than I do; but when it only makes the possessors ridiculously vain, or induces them to tyrannize over the feelings of others, then am I the first to oppose its in∣fluence, and resist its encroaches.

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: Ah, my loved Franzel, from what principle is it that every thing you say carries irresistible conviction!

SP.SPEAKER: Franz.
SP.P: It is because I can have no interest to de∣ceive the person whom I adore; and that love speaks the pure language of the heart.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Curate, hastily.

SP.SPEAKER: Franz.
SP.P: Well, my dear friend, what says—

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.P: (out of breath) Poh, pooh! pooh!—Lord, what a deal of duty do some folks perform!

SP.SPEAKER: Franz.
SP.P: But, my dear friend, where are my father and my mother?

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.P: Pooh!—well, some gentlemen are used like post-horses, I say—pooh!

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: But, my dear Curate, do tell us what do they say?

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.P: O Lord, I am so out of breath, that I can say nothing.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Mefrow, Boterham following.

SP.SPEAKER: Mef.
SP.P: Come along, hubby—where are the children? Well, Franzel—So, Cecil—What, it's all over, is it, and the thing is finish'd, hey?

SP.SPEAKER: Franz.
SP.P: Madam, let me present to you the most charming of her sex. Will you, sir, give me your blessing? [Kneels.

SP.SPEAKER: Boter.
SP.P: Give! all in good time—but come, get up; there's no occasion to be upon your knees, as I used say to my old Flanders mare.

SP.SPEAKER: Mef.
SP.P: Well, Cecil, as you are married, mind and behave well, and take care of your house, and look af∣ter your servants, and be a good wife, and move about, d'ye see, and manage your family, and love hubby, and I, and be a dutiful daughter, and then a fig for your father.

SP.SPEAKER: Boter.
SP.P: Aye, a fig for him, indeed. Well, I can't say but I'm rather happy at this event, because he'll be so wretched. What's one man's gain is another man's loss, as Blink Balance used to say.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Hogrestan, (endeavouring to keep the Baron back) Dagran following.

SP.SPEAKER: Hog.
SP.P: Pray, Baron, keep the line of march; the enemy may surprize us.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: Zounds! let me come forward; I say I will get at her.

SP.SPEAKER: Dag.
SP.P: Ah! he has broke through the ranks, and thrown the whole army into disorder.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: (advancing, haughtily) My absolute orders are, that you instantly return to your father. (Going to seize her.)

SP.SPEAKER: Franz.
SP.P: Hold, sir; I must inform you, that I claim a dearer title over this lady, that of husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: Impossible!

SP.SPEAKER: Hog.
SP.P: Impudent!

SP.SPEAKER: Dag.
SP.P: Infamous!

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.P: Aye, but it's true, for I did it myself.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P:
Thou diabolical fellow! By the arms of my fami∣ly!
And have you had the assurance? And thou most dege∣generate offspring! I cou'd easily have forgiven the fir error you had fallen into—but to marry! never was our illustrious family in such a humiliating situation▪ But I must keep up the dignity of my name. Signior Hogrestran, you have lost a wife—but no matter.—

SP.SPEAKER: Dag.
SP.P: No, it is no great matter to my master.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: Psha! Signor Hogrestan, (pushing him out) look not at her; think no more of the living, the dead only ar respectable. (Exit with Hogrestan and Dagran.)

SP.SPEAKER: Mef.
SP.P: Come, let us away to Holland. That's the place for dispatch; so let's lose no time. But they for our own country, and we'll take▪ little Japan black along with us. (To the Curate.)

SP.SPEAKER: Boter.
SP.P: True, Frow, and he shall white-wash us the rest of our days.

SP.SPEAKER: Curate.
SP.P: Ay, black or white, it's all the same to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Cecil.
SP.P: Hold, dear Madam Boterham; let me first pacify my father.

SP.SPEAKER: Boter.
SP.P: Pacify! whey and butter-milk, what sig∣nifies pacifying people, when there's nothing to be got by it?

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Serjeant, and whispers Franzel.

SP.SPEAKER: Franz.
SP.P: Recruits at the Eagle?

SP.SPEAKER: Mef.
SP.P: Psha! my son can't think of recruits now; he has other duty to do.

SP.SPEAKER: Boter.
SP.P: Gadstedlikins, so he has, and enough too; but come, son, we'll endeavour to get you leave of ab∣sence from this damn'd piping and drumming, and then away for Holland. He! Cecil, that's the country for business of all sorts, as my wife says.

SP.SPEAKER: Curate.
SP.P: Ay, then I may chance to be doing—But here are all the villagers coming to help to cele∣brate the nuptials: so let's sing and be merry, and stir about as much as we can; for in all weddings that's the way to be happy.

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.L: Then hey for a wedding, my lads and my lasses,
Be merry and cheary, and make a great rout;
Shake hands with old Time as he jollily passes,
And thump it, and bump it, and jump it about;
No pride shall perplex us, no care shall annoy,
In spite of the Baron contented we'll be,
And ev'ry condition shall freely enjoy
The comforts that spring from the family tree.
Chorus repeated.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.L: Love to pride shall not surrender,
Youth does softer joys expect;
Nature, of her children tender,
Will their dearest rights protect.

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.L: Happy the fair whom Love rewards
With Hymen's choice and willing hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.L: When beauty decks,

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.L: When honour guards,

SP.SPEAKER: Both.
SP.L: When fond affection links the band.

SP.SPEAKER: Myn.
SP.L: Well, dear:

SP.SPEAKER: Mef.
SP.L: Well, Hubb, what say you now;
Is it niet good?

SP.SPEAKER: Myn.
SP.L: Yaw well, my frow.

SP.SPEAKER: Mef.
SP.L: Something I knew they would be at.

SP.SPEAKER: Myn.
SP.L: I always said you knew what's what.

SP.SPEAKER: Bot.
SP.L: Then thump it, and bump it, and jump it about,
And heartily let us in wishes agree,
That all our kind patrons, within and without,
May join to encourage the family tree.

LG.L: Then thump it, and bump it, and jump it about,
And heartily let us in wishes agree,
That all our kind patrons, within and without,
May join to encourage the family tree.

DIV1.HEAD: Of T. CADELL, Bookeller, opposite Catherine-street, Strand, may be had the following Pieces.
DIV1.P: BONDUCA: a Tragedy, written by Beaumont and Fletcher, with Alterations.

THE DEVIL UPON TWO STICKS, THE MAID OF BATH, The COZENERS, The NABOB, and The TRIP TO CALAIS, to which is annexed The CAPUCHI, all written by the late SAMUEL FOOTE, Esq; and published by Mr. COLMAN. Also
The TAILORS, a Tragedy for warm weather.

BUXOM JOAN, a Burletta in one Act, and the Airs, Duets, Trios, and Finale introduced in the Comedy of the SPANISH BARBER; Likewise SUMMER AMUSEMENT; or, An ADVENTURE AT MARGATE, a Comic Opera; and the Airs, Duets, and Trios in the Musical Farce called The SON-IN-LAW, as they are all performed at the Theatre-Royal in the Hay-Market.
The MANAGER IN DISTRESS, a Prelude, no open∣ing the Hay-Market Theatre, May 30, 1780. Writ∣ten by GEORGE COLMAN.
The Songs, Duets, Chorusses, &c. in the Musical Farce of The DEAD ALIVE, by the same Author.
TONY LUMPKIN IN TOWN, a Farce, written by J. KEEFFE, Author of the SON-IN-LAW.
